title: How to Make Kadai Paneer

steps.headline: Mix the coriander seeds and dried chilies together.
steps.description: Grind it into a fine powder. Alternatively, you could first roast the coriander seeds and chilies until they become a bit red and grind them into a fine powder. You can use a spice grinder or a mixer. Set this aside.

steps.headline: Place a pan on the stove and heat it.
steps.description: Add 2-3 teaspoons of oil or ghee and let it heat. Put in the ginger-garlic paste and sauté.

steps.headline: Fry the veggies.
steps.description: Add the onions and fry until the raw aroma goes away or until they turn a bit brown. Add the tomatoes and capsicum and sauté until they become soft.

steps.headline: Add the kadai masala and fry for a minute.
Add the pureed tomato and stir continuously.
steps.description: Let it fry for at least 2 minutes or until the puree becomes a bit thicker.

steps.headline: Add the spices.
steps.description: Add the garam masala, chicken masala, daniya powder, and salt to get the desired taste. If you want a bit more gravy, then you can add a bit of water. Make sure to adjust the spices after adding water.

steps.headline: Fry the paneer in a pan with butter until it turns golden brown.
steps.description: Add these paneer cubes to the gravy and simmer for 3-4 minutes.

steps.headline: Make any final adjustments.
steps.description: If you feel your gravy is a bit too spicy, you can add ½ teaspoon of butter or cream.

steps.headline: Add the coriander leaves or kasoori methi leaves at the end for garnish.
steps.description: Serve hot with naan or roti!

text: Kadai Paneer with Gravy Mix the coriander seeds and dried chilies together. Grind it into a fine powder. Alternatively, you could first roast the coriander seeds and chilies until they become a bit red and grind them into a fine powder. You can use a spice grinder or a mixer. Set this aside. Place a pan on the stove and heat it. Add 2-3 teaspoons of oil or ghee and let it heat. Put in the ginger-garlic paste and sauté. Fry the veggies. Add the onions and fry until the raw aroma goes away or until they turn a bit brown. Add the tomatoes and capsicum and sauté until they become soft. Add the kadai masala and fry for a minute.  Add the pureed tomato and stir continuously. Let it fry for at least 2 minutes or until the puree becomes a bit thicker. Add the spices. Add the garam masala, chicken masala, daniya powder, and salt to get the desired taste. If you want a bit more gravy, then you can add a bit of water. Make sure to adjust the spices after adding water. Fry the paneer in a pan with butter until it turns golden brown. Add these paneer cubes to the gravy and simmer for 3-4 minutes. Make any final adjustments. If you feel your gravy is a bit too spicy, you can add ½ teaspoon of butter or cream. Add the coriander leaves or kasoori methi leaves at the end for garnish. Serve hot with naan or roti! Sabji or Non-Gravy Kadai Paneer Mix the coriander seeds and dried chilies together. Grind it into a fine powder. Alternatively, you could first roast the coriander seeds and chilies until they become a bit red and grind them into a fine powder. You can use a spice grinder or a mixer. Set this aside. Place a pan and heat 2-3 teaspoons of oil/ghee in it. Add the ginger garlic paste and sauté. Fry the veggies. Add the onions and fry until they turn golden brown or until the raw aroma fades away. Add the capsicum and fry until they become soft. Add the kadai masala. Stir well and sauté for 2-3 minutes. Add the tomatoes and fry until they become soft. Use a spatula or the back of your spoon to mash the mixture. Add a bit of water along with salt, garam masala, chicken masala and daniya powder. Cook for 6-7 minutes. Keep stirring so that it does not burn underneath. Add the paneer and cook for 2-3 minutes.  Add coriander leaves or kasoori methi for garnish.
